back: A stochastic system with one or more inputs and one or more outputs, for which the output(s) is(are) not a deterministic function of the output(s)

For a stochastic system with a discrete input events $\{ A_0, A_i, \ldots \}$ and discrete output events $\{B_0, B_1, \ldots\}$, the likelihoods are the conditional probabilities of the output events given the input events: \[ P(B_j| A_i). \]

For a stochastic system with discrete input events $\{ A_0, A_i, \ldots \}$ and discrete output events $\{B_0, B_1, \ldots\}$, the a posterior probabilities (APPs) are the conditional probabilities of the input events given the observed outputs: \[ P(A_i | B_j). \]
For a stochastic system with discrete input events $\{ A_0, A_i, \ldots \}$, the a priori probabilities are the probabilities of the input events before any output is observed: \[ P(A_i). \]

Given likelihoods $P(B_j|A_i)$ and a prioris $P(A_i)$, the a posteriori probabilities (APPs) can be written as \[ P(A_i|B_j) = \frac{P\left(B_j \left \vert A_i \right. \right) P\left( A_i \right)} { \sum_i P\left(B_j \left \vert A_i \right. \right) P\left( A_i \right)} \]
Assuming the likelihoods will determine the probabilities and negelecting the a prioris, which give some base rate at which one of the phenomena occurs.
